text: XXX in a comment is usually a heads-up.
It could be:

lis.text: Something that's not implemented completely correctly.
Something that should be fixed later on.
Something you're not sure about, a question.

text: I've often preferred a more descriptive tag like FIXME or TODO or HACK.
XXX is often used as a catch all for the above.
Searching for 'XXX' on the FreeBSD code cross reference is a good example of many of the uses.
There are thousands...
Some notes from a June 2005 Python Enhancement Proposal that was rejected.

childList.text: June 2005 Python Enhancement Proposal that was rejected

text: The PEP Starts with,
The PEP is an interesting read.
I use XXX because it's easier to type than TODO.
XXX is for when you're in a hurry and will get back to this yourself.
TODO is for when you have to hand it off to someone else.
Probably it's for cases that you don't know how to handle.
Check out this: List view of TODO/FIXME/XXX/HACK statements

lis.text: NOTE: Description of how the code works (when it isn't self evident)
XXX: Warning about possible pitfalls, can be used as NOTE:XXX:
HACK: Not very well written or malformed code to circumvent a problem/bug. Should be used as HACK:FIXME:
FIXME: This works, sort of, but it could be done better. (usually code written in a hurry that needs rewriting)
BUG: There is a problem here.
TODO: No problem, but addtional code needs to be written (usually when you are skipping something)

text: At least this is how I was taught about these tags.
Basically the first two (NOTE and XXX) are used for information and no action is required.
While the last three (FIXME, BUG and TODO) Do require action.
HACK is somewhere in between (and hardly ever used I think?
A placeholder, usually implying the code it refers to is:
or worse.
